etymologies: late 17th century; earliest use found in Thomas Philipot (d. 1682), poet and writer. From classical Latin simpulum earthenware ladle or pouring vessel used in religious ceremonies, alteration (after -ulum) of simpuvium, in the same sense, of uncertain origin; perhaps from ancient Greek σιπύη meal-tub, of uncertain origin, or perhaps a loan from a Semitic language

definitions: A small ladle or other vessel used to pour out wine, especially as an offering to a god.
